title: التَّقْدِيمُ وَالتَّأْخِيرُ
description: Learn about التقديم والتأخير - the rules governing word order in Arabic, including obligatory and permissible fronting of subjects, objects, predicates, and other sentence elements.

notes.title: Introduction to Word Order
content: Arabic has relatively flexible word order compared to many languages, but this flexibility follows specific rules. التَّقْدِيم (fronting/advancing) moves an element earlier in the sentence, while التَّأْخِير (delaying) moves it later.
Word order changes can be وَاجِب (obligatory), جَائِز (permissible), or مُمْتَنِع (prohibited). Understanding these rules is essential for both correct grammar and proper rhetorical effect.

examples.english: Zayd hit Amr (normal order: verb-subject-object)
Zayd hit Amr (subject fronted)
Amr, Zayd hit (object fronted)
In the house is Zayd (predicate fronted)

notes.title: Obligatory Fronting of Predicate (تقديم الخبر وجوبًا)
content: The predicate (خَبَر) must be fronted before the subject (مُبْتَدَأ) in several cases: 1) When the predicate is a prepositional phrase and the subject is indefinite (نكرة), 2) When the subject has a pronoun referring back to the predicate, 3) When the predicate is a question word (أَيْنَ، مَتَى، كَيْفَ).
These rules prevent ambiguity and maintain Arabic grammatical principles like the requirement that مُبْتَدَأ generally be definite (معرفة).
keyPoints: Predicate = prepositional, subject = نكرة: front predicate
Subject has pronoun referring to predicate: front predicate
Predicate is question word: front predicate

examples.english: In the house is a man (must front predicate - subject is نكرة)
I have a book (prepositional predicate + indefinite subject)
In the cage is its bird (pronoun in subject refers to predicate)
Where is Zayd? (question word must be first)

notes.title: Obligatory Fronting of Subject (تقديم المبتدأ وجوبًا)
content: The subject (مُبْتَدَأ) must come before the predicate (خَبَر) in certain cases: 1) When the subject is a question word (مَنْ، مَا), 2) When the subject has لام الابتداء, 3) When subject and predicate are equally definite and no context distinguishes them.
These rules ensure proper grammatical structure and clear communication.
keyPoints: Subject is question word: must be first
Subject has لام الابتداء: must be first

examples.english: Who is in the house? (مَنْ must be مبتدأ first)
Indeed Zayd is standing (لام الابتداء requires subject first)
Allah is our Lord (both definite - subject first)
What is knowledge? (مَا question = subject)

notes.title: Obligatory Fronting of Object (تقديم المفعول وجوبًا)
content: The object (مَفْعُول بِهِ) must be fronted before the verb in several cases: 1) When the object is a question word (مَنْ رَأَيْتَ؟), 2) When the object is كَمْ or أَيّ in interrogative use, 3) When the object has a pronoun that refers to the subject.
Fronting the object often adds emphasis or is required by the nature of question words which must appear first.
keyPoints: Object is question word: must front
Object is كَمْ/أَيّ interrogative: must front
Object has pronoun referring to subject: must front

examples.english: Whom did you see? (مَنْ must be first)
How many books did you read? (كَمْ must be first)
Which man did you meet? (أَيّ must be first)
You alone we worship (Quran - object fronted for restriction)

notes.title: Permissible Word Order Changes
content: In many cases, word order changes are جَائِز (permissible) but not obligatory. These changes are often made for بَلَاغَة (rhetoric), emphasis, or stylistic variety.

Common permissible changes include: fronting the object for emphasis, fronting adverbs (ظروف) for focus, and rearranging elements in compound sentences. The default order is verb-subject-object, but variation is common.

examples.arabic: ضَرَبَ زَيْدٌ عَمْرًا / عَمْرًا ضَرَبَ زَيْدٌ
examples.english: Zayd hit Amr / Amr, Zayd hit (permissible change for emphasis)
Yesterday Zayd came (adverb fronted for focus)
The book I read (object fronted for specification)
In the name of Allah I begin (prepositional phrase fronted)

notes.title: Prohibited Word Order Changes
content: Some word order changes are مُمْتَنِع (prohibited) because they would cause ambiguity, grammatical error, or loss of meaning. The prohibition ensures Arabic maintains its logical structure.

Examples of prohibited changes: separating جَارّ وَمَجْرُور (preposition and its noun), separating مُضَاف وَمُضَاف إِلَيْهِ (construct state), fronting a governed element before its governor when it would cause confusion.

examples.arabic: ذَهَبْتُ إِلَى الْمَسْجِدِ ✓ / ذَهَبْتُ الْمَسْجِدِ إِلَى ✗
examples.english: I went to the mosque (cannot separate preposition from noun)
Zayd's book (cannot separate construct state)
I saw Zayd's servant (مضاف إليه follows مضاف)
Since a year (preposition must precede noun)

exercises.prompt: نَقْلُ عُنْصُرٍ إِلَى مَوْضِعٍ سَابِقٍ فِي الْجُمْلَةِ يُسَمَّى _____
exercises.promptEn: Moving an element to an earlier position in the sentence is called _____

exercises.prompt: فِي الدَّارِ رَجُلٌ - تَقْدِيمُ الْخَبَرِ هُنَا _____ لِأَنَّ الْمُبْتَدَأَ نَكِرَة
exercises.promptEn: In the house is a man - fronting the predicate here is _____ because the subject is indefinite

exercises.prompt: مَنْ رَأَيْتَ؟ - تَقْدِيمُ مَنْ وَاجِبٌ لِأَنَّ أَدَاةَ الاِسْتِفْهَامِ لَهَا _____
exercises.promptEn: Whom did you see? - Fronting مَنْ is obligatory because question words have _____

exercises.prompt: تَقْدِيمُ الْمَفْعُولِ بِهِ لِلتَّأْكِيدِ أَوِ التَّخْصِيصِ يَكُونُ _____، لَيْسَ وَاجِبًا
exercises.promptEn: Fronting the object for emphasis or specification is _____, not obligatory
Separating the مُضَاف and مُضَاف إِلَيْهِ is _____

exercises.prompt: إِيَّاكَ نَعْبُدُ - قُدِّمَ الْمَفْعُولُ بِهِ هُنَا لِإِفَادَةِ _____
exercises.promptEn: You alone we worship - the object is fronted here to convey _____

exercises.answer: Fronting / moving an element earlier in the sentence
Delaying / moving an element later in the sentence
Priority / the right to come first (for question words etc.)

exercises.prompt: An obligatory word order change that must be made
A permissible word order change for emphasis or style
A prohibited word order change that would cause error
